description: From un- +‎ ravel. Compare Dutch ontrafelen (“to unravel”).

verbs.description: unravel (third-person singular simple present unravels, present participle unravelling or (US) unraveling, simple past and past participle unravelled or (US) unraveled)

examples: Stop playing with the seam of the tablecloth! You'll unravel it.
Mother couldn't unravel the ball of wool after the cat had played with it.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of threads etc.) To become separated; (of something woven, knitted, etc.) to come apart.
examples: Of woven cloud unravel in pale air:

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To clear from complication or difficulty; to unfold; to solve.
(transitive, figurative) To separate the connected or united parts of; to throw into disorder; to confuse.
examples: Art shall be conjured for it, and nature all unravelled.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figurative) To become undone; to collapse.
examples: The great Ponzi scheme that lies behind our State pension is unravelling – as they all do eventually – because money being taken from new investors is insufficient to honour promises issued to earlier generations.
